description: With dreamy experimental production and standout Tyler, the Creator features, the L.A. singer’s latest is an affecting document of how pain can smolder beneath a veneer of nonchalance.
Willow’s fourth solo album continues to unpack her lifelong struggles with the extremes of human emotion, using a trove of pop-rock stylings from nu-metal to pop-punk to somewhat mixed effect.
Feigning coupledom, the two singers offer a fictionalized divorce album modeled after the tear-jerking country, soul, and pop duets of yesteryear. They flirt with camp without ever succumbing to it.
Traversing classic UK genres like 2-step and jungle, the duo’s first commercial mix doubles as a celebration of multiculturalism in modern Britain.
With cosmos-filling drones and blazing noise, the third album from Madeline Johnston’s experimental pop project feels ambitious and communal.
Working with producer Dave Sitek, Nathan Williams returns with another mixed bag of combative rock songs that are straightforward to a fault.
Pop Smoke’s second posthumous album sounds like it’s solely designed to generate clicks as a new generation of rap fans continues to be exploited for their streams.

Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today we revisit Annie Lennox’s 1992 solo debut, a joyous and liberated pop album with a prophetic message about the disillusionment of fame.
is the sound of a man alone in his success. Even if this is one of John Mayer’s stronger albums, the whole thing feels self-consciously minor.
The 20-year-old TikTok personality turned punk rocker’s debut album won’t stop announcing how punk it is.
The no-holds-bar rapper and producer weave a tight tapestry of musical references that only hundreds of hours spent sweating to music by queer elders could produce.
The debut EP from this reverential emo band is full of nostalgia, wonder, and autobiographical detail, like a Linklater film soundtracked by Deep Elm Records.
On her second album, reluctant Gen Z ambassador Clairo turns back the clock, embracing classic touchstones of 1970s folk.
Chicago multi-instrumentalist Nick Levine’s solo debut will feel familiar to Pinegrove fans but struggles to expand on the band’s formula.
Powered by brittle electronic drums and buzzing synths, the Congolese musician’s debut album is simultaneously bleak and exhilarating.
Originally released in 1999 as a promotional CD-R, this collection of alternate mixes and non-album tracks bridges the gap between the band’s experimental hijinks and pop instincts.
George Lewis Jr.’s self-titled fifth album is an island of good feelings and vacuous summertime indie-pop jams.
Dave Grohl’s six-piece finds common cause between gaudy disco-pop and willfully absurd arena rock on an album-length collection of Bee Gees covers and live-in-studio   cuts.

album: Fun Is Not a Straight Line
description: Sasu Ripatti—aka Vladislav Delay and Luomo—returns to footwork with his first album-length attempt at the form, translating the genre’s fast-paced syncopations into a harsh, elemental blast.
These 1981 devotional recordings for voice and Wurlitzer, meant to guide meditation through chanting, offer an alternate version of the cosmic jazz visionary’s synthesizer masterpiece,  .

The Monterrey-based experimental musician abandons the outward trappings of electronic music on his latest album, a hushed collection of cryptic etudes that flicker in the margin between the played and the programmed.
Created during a residency at Gainesville’s Pulp Arts studio, Nandi Rose’s latest album as Half Waif is complex, daring, and emotionally unsettled.
The 23-year-old singer’s careful observations add new profundity to her storytelling. Her second album confirms her place as one of modern R&B’s realest talkers.
With a new rhythm section and tighter performances, the noisy New York band’s latest EP moves deliberately from chaos to catharsis.
The Australian musician caps an adventurous trilogy of EPs with another round of plush, laid-back songs that effortlessly mix pop, rap, R&B, and reggae.
The Nigerian rapper and singer’s easygoing charm guides this lush and freewheeling collection.
Breakout UK producer Tim Reaper and his collaborator Comfort Zone convey the power and possibility of jungle.

Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today we revisit the grandiose British rock band’s second album, a supranatural space odyssey powered by all-too-human emotion.
New Zealand psych rocker Connan Mockasin’s collaborative album with his dad, Ade, has bad jokes, stream-of-consciousness poetry, and an odd, undeniable appeal.
Much like the cinematic remake, which functions as nothing but an advertisement for the entire Warner Media library, the   soundtrack is soulless and gratuitous.
On his first proper full-length in three years, the Japanese electronic musician collages tiny sounds into intricate grooves that harness the wonder of everyday life.
The nascent pop star attempts to move beyond reggaetón on his latest album, but he never fully commits to any particular direction.
On his new mixtape, the South Florida rapper is content honing the blade of his technical precision while his peers take direct stabs at crossover success.
Singer and songwriter Maya Bon’s bedroom-pop dirges are both intimate and removed, filled with understated yet strangely meaningful detail.
Raime’s Joe Andrews and Tom Halstead, together with percussionist Valentina Magaletti, swap their customary electronics for muscular, guitar-driven sounds influenced by bands like Slint and Unwound.
Guided by the inquisitive lyrics of singer Audrey Kang as she narrates the process of searching for self through song, the band’s lush third album feels like a ride-along to the creative process.
The Brisbane trio immerses itself in cavernous, eerie post-punk to soundtrack the uncanny horror of young adulthood.
Arriving a full 10 years after his debut single, Welsh producer Lewis Roberts’ first album is a bravura display of brain-bending editing that’s more concerned with big feelings.
Produced entirely by Kenny Beats, the album’s reserved musical approach magnifies the blunt scene-setting Vince has used to build his name over the last decade.
On their first album in nearly a decade, Jakob Dylan and co. return with highway ballads and Saturday afternoon rockers, sounding like the classic rock band they’ve always ached to be.

Manchester post-punk musician Julie Campbell’s third album is dense with possibilities, whiplashing between past and future. The maximalism isn’t big-picture, but granular: busy, hyperreal instants by the millions.

album: Let the Soil Play Its Simple Part
description: Centering her own voice for the first time, Caroline Shaw proves to be a master of collapsing boundaries, whether between her performer-composer roles or the corporeal and the immaterial.

Three 6 Mafia’s tireless frontman has done it all as an artist and collaborator, which is why it’s disappointing to see him combat his ageless production with uninspired guest features on his new deluxe album.
The newly independent singer’s latest project is designed to make her stand out in a crowded R&B field but falls short of any singular, defining moments.

album: I LIE HERE BURIED WITH MY RINGS AND MY DRESSES
description: The Zambian Canadian rapper and producer’s third album is heavy and suffocating, cranking up the murk and intensity to reveal the relief within unbridled anger.
The Guatemalan musician’s second album explores the friction between interiority and exteriority; blooming with ecstatic synth riffs and spirited cello, the record captures the sound of a mind abuzz.

On her debut album, the Toronto singer-songwriter and producer draws variously from gospel, folk, and adult-contemporary influences; no matter the style, every song is a showcase for her powerful voice.
An extended investigation of the electric guitar solo, the latest record from Ben Chasny’s experimental project is graceful and surprising.
The Melbourne jangle-pop quartet hits all the right ‘80s pleasure points with an understated sense of humor and anthemic songcraft.
The New York City rap crew’s latest is a mansion of sweet beats and vocal textures that bring a whole new level of professional polish to their sound.
On the strongest album of their unlikely second act, the Swedish melodic death metal band lets their weirder side take the reins.
Despite its grand scope and good intentions, the latest album from M.C. Taylor is the sound of an artist beginning to repeat himself: lite music for dark times.
A gloomier companion to 2020’s  , John Darnielle’s latest is patient, tense, and full of empathy.
The UK musician’s latest release is her most substantial work yet, adding a new sense of momentum to her ambient dream pop.
The noisy, cosmic trio of Philadelphia DIY lifers returns with an unearthed studio album. It’s an upgrade in fidelity and a shit-ton of fun.
The elusive UK group’s third album in just over a year—to be made available online for only 99 days—renders Black trauma in the eerie, sing-song cadences of children’s rhymes.
Once united in their status as industry misfits, the four-man supergroup has reassembled for a fan-service album that hinges upon a certain taste for bars.

album: Get Lost in the Music EP
description: The New Jersey singer-songwriter’s five-song EP tries out different frames for her strikingly powerful voice, variously exploring reggaetón, futuristic Americana, and psychedelic club pop.
The 23-year-old songwriter’s debut renders tales of young love and its quandaries with diaristic lyrics and anguished singing. She’s at her best when she’s plainspoken and immediate.
A long-lost recording captures the Ethiopian organist and his band at the Hilton Addis Ababa in 1975, laying down deceptively breezy jazz songs steeped in nameless longing.

Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today we revisit Laurie Anderson’s grand theatrical treatise, an avant-garde piece comprised of sound sculpture and rock music, gender and social studies, philosophy and linguistics.

album: Born This Way the Tenth Anniversary
description: A decade ago, Lady Gaga created an enormous, bravura flex of electronic pop. An anniversary edition arrives with six “reimagined” versions of its songs by LGBTQ+ artists and allies.

album: To Enjoy Is the Only Thing
description: The Melbourne-based songwriter’s debut is sparse and hypnotic, drawing connections between her experiences of leaving a relationship and leaving a religious upbringing.
Indie aesthetics have changed considerably in the past two decades, but the UK group is still throwing block parties for a utopia where time and genre collapse.

Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today we revisit Billy Joel’s greatest album, a sublimely crafted breakthrough that finds the meeting ground of the romantic and the mundane.

album: Call Me If You Get Lost
description: With DJ Drama in tow, Tyler thrives in the realm of the rap mixtape, which allows him great freedom to explore every facet of his talent as a producer, writer, and vocalist.

The band’s first new album in six years is a procession of pinging, clanging, reverberating tactile pleasures, an inventive backdrop for Isaac Brock’s familiar blend of forced optimism and unforced paranoia.
No longer content with merely capturing the sound of four wildly talented musicians in a room together, the Australian “future soul” group transforms on their vibrant and psychedelic third album.
Informed by their study of Zen Buddhism, Danielle L. Davis and Steven Whiteley create spacious, playful synthesizer melodies that push at the boundaries of what “meditative” music can be.
The post-punk band’s new seven-song collection owes a conspicuous debt to New Order, and while the presentation begs to be called “spooky,” they’re having fun with it.

album: How Much Time It Is Between You and Me?
description: Recorded in a mountain village, the Russian ambient musician’s debut album molds field recordings and hushed vocals into a form that’s richly textured and occasionally unsettling.
The myth-skewing, Oakland-based artist is a chameleonic pop singer on her third album. Whimsical and urgent, these are fairy tales meant to wake us up.
Equally indebted to pioneering girl groups and her punk heroes, the New York singer-songwriter’s debut is a fiery exploration of love, anger, and coming-of-age.
The Brooklyn songwriter and sound artist’s second album is a kind of spiritual accounting, a swirling blend of orchestral groans and human whispers that evokes subconscious drift.
On Ella Williams’ second album as Squirrel Flower, the road is a space of intimacy and disaster. Her vivid songwriting and bright, searching voice bring both sides to life.
The Flint-raised, Houston-based rapper is known for his outrageous punchlines, but the engine of his raps is the personality-filled flow and the piano-driven Michigan beat.
The composer and percussionist’s latest work is intricate and eerie, drawing attention to the small sounds that slip unnoticed in the chorus of a busy day.

The French musician’s giddily maximalist solo debut maintains the spirit of his group Justice’s debut album; though inspired by ’70s prog and disco, it inhabits a singular universe of its own invention.
There is so much depth to Faye Webster’s dazzling fourth album. It strikes a perfect balance between classic country stoicism and the sound of the saddest person you follow on social media.
Addressing faith, young love, and nostalgia, the songwriter’s autobiographical third album is empathetic yet unsparing, catchy and finely crafted.
The Oakland band’s darkly psychedelic country folk suggests things on the verge of collapse. In March 2020, as singer Sawyer Gebauer unwittingly contracted COVID-19, that was truer than anyone knew.
The third album from the extremely chaotic pop star, battle rapper, and edgelord is a thrilling ride that puts her eclecticism on full display.
Mamiffer’s Faith Coloccia pressed her music—faintly liturgical songs and sound poems about self and motherhood—onto dubplates for turntablist Philip Jeck to smear and distort, to uncanny effect.
The long-awaited debut from the lauded singer and guitarist is a fine showcase of her immense talent, though the constant balladeering doesn’t really capture what she does best.
On this elaborate concept album, initially released in monthly installments, the hardcore collective reclaims its status as the most fearless prog-punk band of them all.
MIKE’s place in the vanguard of New York underground rap has invigorated him. It would be a stretch to call this album happy, but the atmosphere is undeniably warmer and more hopeful.
The Asheville songwriter’s newly reissued debut divulges her restless thoughts through folksy garage-pop that’s both vulnerable and fierce.
By blending everyday stories with spacey beats, the Savannah rapper makes the mundane unexpectedly entrancing.
The Amsterdam-based electronic musician trades his habitual house and ambient productions for blissful bedroom pop influenced by the shoegaze music of his youth.
The Chicago rapper steps further into the mainstream on his third album, an ultimately hopeful exploration of how trauma manifests.
With flourishes of R&B, house, and funk, this exuberant and sweltering nine-track mini-album nails the transition from left-of-center cult favorite to bona fide diva.

Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today we revisit an uncompromising debut, pop music that ventures to the extremes of sound and emotion.

album: Delusive Tongue Shifts - Situation Based Compositions
description: His name is short for “The International Billionaire’s Secret Love Child,” and his ambient pieces are weightless as a sigh, splotchy as a bruise, both cozy and unsettling.
On a collaborative EP with the 1975’s Matty Healy and George Daniel, the former TikTok phenom devotes herself to the ambiance of late-’90s guitar-pop.
A set of intimate, in-studio performances from Matthew Houck’s creative breakthrough in the early 2010s reveals new meaning and intensity in his tough-hearted songs.
The sequel to 2014’s beloved   is a brief but thrilling project from the mercurial artist, featuring the most approachable music of his career.
Collaborating with artists like Mr Eazi, Burna Boy, and Sampa the Great, the Beninese icon builds upon a proudly pan-Africanist musical vision that celebrates the power of community.
Continuing to mature into a more grown-up image, the nine-member K-pop girl group balances self-contentment and romantic confidence with breezy summer thrill-seeking.
An intensely personal document, the Tennessee singer and guitarist’s third album examines the realities of being a Southern Black LGBTQ+ woman in songs both defiant and vulnerable.
The UK band’s enormous third album is pristine and emotionally extravagant, the platonic ideal for contemporary big-tent rock music.
The proudly campy hyperpop singer’s debut is vibrant and ridiculous, for better or worse.
On their first self-produced record and first in 24 years without drummer Janet Weiss, Sleater-Kinney find pleasant comfort and not much else with down-the-middle rock tunes.

After a 12-year hiatus, the Norwegian duo returns with an especially airbrushed take on easy-listening pop. At their best, the Kings sound deceptively effortless, but the facade is sometimes too smooth.
The Los Angeles-via-Toronto singer offers a finely wrought EP that showcases her oceanic voice and her austere songwriting.
Layering reverberating guitar melodies with subtle electronic sound design and foggy atmospheres, the ambient musician formerly known as Ulla Straus has a way of making the vaporous feel intimate.
The Rochester rapper is at his best when he isn’t folding to the pressures of wider appeal or tightly-packaged collaborations on his latest project.
In this 2015 set marking his retirement from live performance, the veteran improvising guitarist explores the simpler, starker side of his abstract, purposefully formless music.
Maroon 5’s seventh album sets out to experiment beyond their comfort zone. It sounds like a band trying desperately to appeal to as many markets as possible.

album: Ancient Dreams in a Modern Land
description: The unmistakably dramatic pop singer seeks the divine feminine, embracing a bold yet soft aesthetic that’s more effective than some of her lyrics.
Album number 18 was recorded in the band’s homes during the pandemic, and trades psych-rock blitzes for a finely-woven sprawl of synth programming and MIDI sequences.

This unlikely electronic trio—featuring the Chili Peppers’ John Frusciante, Venetian Snares’ Aaron Funk, and noise musician Chris McDonald—cherry-picks from 11 years of dazzlingly complex improvisations.
On their first album in five years, Nick Thorburn’s ever-evolving band takes a pop-friendly turn. With neon synths and disco grooves, these songs are Top 40 at heart.
The rap trio’s latest, like its predecessor, can become a slog and at times seems shoddily constructed. But at its best, the album is a callback to their inspired peak.
The fearless work of the late avant-garde pianist is celebrated with a momentous new anthology, showcasing his immense talent and passion.

Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today we revisit the groundbreaking 1995 soundtrack that changed Bollywood forever.
With pop stars once again performing garish exaggerations of what seems like real personal trauma, Shirley Manson & co. have timed their return perfectly.
The fifth installment of the rapper-producer’s long-running series lands closer to the sweet spot between beats and bars glimpsed on his previous effort.
With influences ranging from Afrobeat to choral symphonies, the Brooklyn-based group’s debut is bright and bursting with detail.
Built around his new custom synthesizer, the latest project from the electronic musician and Nine Inch Nails member offers some of his liveliest music yet.

album: The Rich Are Only Defeated When Running for Their Lives
description: Backed by veteran jazz musicians and newer players, the Trinidad-born, London-based poet summons spirits of the Caribbean diaspora to ask what it might take to build a better world.
Compiling several years’ worth of material and spanning nearly two hours, the Munich producer’s first full-length since 2018 feels cohesive, virtuosic, and thrillingly physical.
After a viral sample made her feathery vocals famous, the singer-songwriter arrives on her own terms with a debut that flits effortlessly between guitar-based soul, alt-pop, and R&B.
Montreal musicians Ouri and Helena Deland recorded their debut album together in eight days; the album’s eight songs feel like the diary of a gradual mind meld.
Michelle Zauner embraces the spotlight and goes for the brass ring on her third album, a stylish and eclectic record that feels of the moment and also steeped in classic indie sensibilities.

Connecting Kansas City and Melbourne, Picnic’s debut full-length is rounded out by a more than an hour’s worth of remixes by artists like Huerco S. and Dntel—a celebration of ambient music as a social phenomenon.
Drawing inspiration from narrative thrust of video-game soundtracks and sound design of trap and trance, the London producer revels in melodramatic builds and spaced-out bliss.
The Berlin producer is a master of negative space and biomechanical sound, lacing her uneasy compositions with voices that excavate images of unceasing loneliness and longing.

On his first release in six years, the UK producer trades the atmospheric grime of his debut for a more driving techno sound, lush enough for headphones but punchy enough to keep one foot on the dancefloor.
The Birmingham duo’s 2001 debut introduced their nightmarish hybrid of black metal, grindcore, and electronic music. On a new reissue, it sounds as extreme and subversive as ever.
The Texas rapper’s second album shows a great talent struggling to find her place while focusing on what she does best: aggressive, take-no-prisoner bars.

On their debut album, the Lahore band blends the free-form improvisation of Hindustani classical and jazz with sample-heavy production creating a musical dialogue about faith, spirituality, and the self.
The teen rapper’s dreamy yet dark mixtape leans into gruff flows and gun-toting punchlines with a wink.
While not quite a marquee work for either artist, the new team-up is reliably consistent and casts them as a natural pair—near-ideal complements to one another in writing and execution.
The London producer’s third album tests the boundaries of dance music not just for the sake of experimentalism, but as an expression of vulnerability and a vehicle for self-knowledge.
On her second EP for Mark Ronson’s Zelig Records, the London multi-media artist proves herself a canny, sophisticated pop stylist with a taste for tales of millennial disaffection.

Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today we revisit the Arizona band’s third album, a giant canvas of rock and pop songwriting that wears its heart on its sleeve.
Though the Swedish rapper still isn’t exactly a crossover star, each album sees him creeping closer to pure pop. His latest features some of his most ear-catching and melodic work yet.

album: This Time I’ll Be of Use
description: The trio’s debut album shifts casually between soulful rap, textured noise, and pensive folk with grace and sometimes too much distance.
The Australian metal band’s sixth album is dense and disorienting, collapsing the boundary between the human voice and machine-made clamor.
The collaborative album by Jay Som’s Melina Duterte and Palehound’s Ellen Kempner tells compelling and rarely heard stories, but doesn’t reach the same highs as their respective solo work.
On their debut album as a quartet, Greg Fox, Melvin Gibbs, Sasha Frere-Jones, and Grey McMurray find common ground in psychedelic post-rock jams that are both sprawling and supremely focused.

album: Feed Me Weird Things (25th Anniversary Edition)
description: First released in 1996, Tom Jenkinson’s debut album feels like a time capsule of the era’s drill’n’bass and jazzy jungle. It’s steeped in inventive rhythms, gorgeous melodies, and giddy fun.
The producer and songwriter’s second solo album is a romantic exploration of uncertainty, a rush of momentum softened by his trademark sounds.
The veteran rapper continues to leverage the same well-worn blueprint on his latest album, which plays like a back-to-basics revue.
Coming on the heels of two stellar 2020 albums, one of the best new voices in underground hip-hop sounds a little looser and lighter, but still keeps his raps bracingly personal.
The product of lockdown recording and late-night walks through London, the Bloc Party frontman’s fifth solo album is as low-key and eccentric as he’s ever sounded.
The alt-rock icon returns with tasteful, timeless rock arrangements on a record about friendship, sobriety, and the love she’d like to receive.
The latest EP from the Irish singer is a set of introspective, velvet-crushed balladry, as much a cohesive mood piece as a collection of individual songs.
The UK band stakes out even more ground on their glorious second album. The chord changes are more elaborate, the rhythms more twisted, the pretty parts prettier, the heavy parts heavier.
The Philadelphia band returns as a three-piece on a pandemic-era EP that introduces subtle shifts in sound and structure. It’s their first release that’s as tender as it is tough.
Recorded over three long, inspired days in a studio north of Rio and newly remastered for its 15th anniversary, this is as solid a dub outing as has issued from anywhere beyond Jamaica.
On this tightly curated EP, the insightful R&B singer revises the elements intrinsic to her work, providing new meditations on Blackness, womanhood, and love.
This 1975 set captures the band reconnecting with the psych-rock fury of its primordial years, drawing from a cleaned-up recording of a super-fan’s tape.
Though it’s full of guests and emotional twists and turns, the late rapper’s posthumous album is largely sloppy and inconsequential, a sour note to bookend a storied legacy.
This 1992 meeting of Moritz von Oswald, Thomas Fehlmann, and Juan Atkins is a monument to the improbable transatlantic alliance that techno forged between Detroit and Berlin.
The Australian-born, UK-based musician hones her songwriting and polishes her production without losing the atmospheric qualities that made the first two albums in this trilogy so captivating.
On one of his most ambitious and definitive projects, Mach-Hommy reunites with Westside Gunn and puts on an unforgettable clinic with his razor-sharp bars and an exceptional eye for detail.
The Brooklyn rapper’s latest project is a ready canvas for her technical skill and well-earned boasts, but she’s at her best when she digs deeper.
On his debut solo album, the Toronto artist formerly known as Mustafa the Poet confronts grief and dispossession over understated production with folk-music overtones.

album: All I Know So Far: Setlist
description: The pop singer architects her legacy with a new documentary and live album from her 2019 tour. As a performer, she’s fun and loose, even as her newest music feels more like a means to an end.
The drummer builds on the transnational foundations of his last ambitious album, making the case for global citizenship and international solidarity through culture-spanning music.

album: The Best of Lily Konigsberg Right Now
description: The cheekily named compilation includes songs from three solo releases, alongside unreleased tracks and bedroom demos that offer a shining mosaic of the New York singer-songwriter’s indie-pop acumen.
Fiddlehead’s second album doesn’t stray far from the band’s foundational qualities: gruff but approachable, intense without being aggro, emo but not  .
Though heavily inspired by ’90s and ’00s R&B, the Portugal-born, Danish musician grows into a quietly commanding presence of her own on her second album.
A new EP of songs originally recorded for 2011’s   illustrate just how well the band’s simultaneously twee- and emo-adjacent indie rock holds up.
The omnivorous Japanese band’s Sub Pop debut exudes a newfound sense of serenity, even as they remain committed to exuberant self-love.
The Atlanta rapper does not go pop on this release, choosing instead to dive deep into his unique blend of horror tales and unsettling production.
The Super Furry Animals frontman’s latest is a concept album about an ancient volcano on the China-North Korea border that ranks among his most imaginative solo records.
The Italian-born, London-based EBM auteur thaws out his industrial chill and embraces optimism, celebrating the fragility and strangeness of human experience with uncommon earnestness.
Following a string of albums deconstructing Lambchop’s sound, Kurt Wagner continues to reinvent his band, this time using MIDI-assisted piano melodies to write love songs to music itself.
On her debut album, the Nashville-based singer-songwriter and her extraordinary voice search for a place to call home.
Four months after “drivers license,” pop’s newest star offers a nimble and lightly chaotic collection of breakup tunes filled with melancholy and mischief.

album: A Little More Time With Reigning Sound
description: Reuniting the Memphis lineup of his long-running band, former Oblivian Greg Cartwright reveals the depth of his appreciation for classic American rock and soul sounds.
The Tuareg guitarist and his bandmates deliver the fullest picture of his gifts yet. Recorded piecemeal during tour breaks, the album captures the group’s easy chemistry and explosive energy.
Shabaka Hutchings leads his brass band on a propulsive mind- and body-moving record, advocating through music that change comes from speaking directly about collective oppression.
Following the camp-infused club music of 2017’s  , Al Qadiri once again examines questions of gender and representation in the Arab world, this time invoking women poets of the Middle Ages.

Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today we revisit the brilliant 1979 album from the Mael brothers that transformed them into future-pop prophets.
The team-up between two West Coast rappers suggests an inspired combination, but it pays off only in intermittent bursts.
The Brighton-based singer’s second album exquisitely recreates the sound of early ’70s AOR, with songs that go straight to the despondent heart.
Developed in collaboration with the Alias dance company, Fernando Corona’s newest solo album is a swirling miasma of ominous drone and murky rhythm that hums like an electrical substation.
The Canadian singer and songwriter’s fourth album is an ambitious collage of ’90s R&B and orchestral dramatics, welded together by her versatile, gossamer voice.
Annie Clark brings the glammy sounds of the ’70s to an album about mothers and daughters, fathers and prison. It’s an audacious and deeply personal record occasionally beset by clunky choices.
The Danny Brown-led squad’s new album is a solid extension of their brand of gully Detroit rap delivered with a crooked snarl.

Originally released as a concert film but now reissued as a live album, this cult favorite reimagines the Pet Shop Boys’ own canon and other pop hits, curating a century of pop music history in one jukebox.
The boisterous UK trio adds polish to its organ house and bassline rap, balancing lyrical economy with over-the-top boasts and catchy choruses.
On his latest album, Keith Rankin programs a virtuosic MIDI cello, tempering awe-inspiring moments with reminders of its synthetic nature.
Reviving Untold’s Hemlock label from a four-year slumber, the UK producer returns with an EP of stripped-down basement tracks bridging dubstep’s early years with club music’s future.
The Philadelphia-born, Berlin-based producer, a former GHE20G0TH1K affiliate, follows a run of incendiary mixtapes with a four-track EP of lacerating, irresistibly kink-positive techno.
On J. Cole’s refreshing and lively new album, the rapper relaxes his grip around the mic and thrives when he’s collaborating, not when he’s making deadly serious legacy raps.
Amid the humble Florida rapper’s croons and raps about life and pain, there’s a unique voice that’s starting to emerge.
The producer and luxury furniture seller gathers the biggest names in rap once again for a market-researched album that’s as repetitive as his catchphrases.
The NYC rapper’s latest is a 22-minute blast of dank, dingy, experimental rhymes that feels too fleeting to be a long-term stylistic shift.
The South Carolina vocalist and producer presents an attainable vision of R&B on his latest EP, an unpretentious suite of pure bedroom music greater than the sum of its vibes.
Rivers Cuomo’s latest is a tribute to his hair metal heroes, but it never goes all that hard.
With stripped-back instrumentation and poignant emotion, the English singer’s latest release is a stopgap EP that punches above its weight.
On their second album, the Brooklyn quartet sinks deeper into their dread-filled chill-out sound, but they become sharper and more focused in the process.

As Dan Auerbach and Patrick Carney breezily enter their third decade together, they pay tribute to and put their own spin on the Mississippi blues, turning it into something that sounds supple and comforting.
A collection of Terre Thaemlitz’s gorgeous and thought-provoking deep-house 12"s turns a critical eye on history, identity, and club culture.
On his solo debut, the Red River Dialect frontman explores personal, spiritual, and musical growth after his nine-month retreat at a Nova Scotia Buddhist monastery.
The Ohio rapper’s new EP makes a compelling case for his brand of self-aware cynicism.
A four-disc set looks back on the brief, fertile period in which the British band twisted conventional rock instrumentation into increasingly arcane shapes. They still inhabit a class of their own.

Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today we revisit the 1996 album from the hip-hop trio, a socially conscious blockbuster grounded by the realities of the immigrant experience.
On his feature-heavy new album, the Oakland rapper takes stock of his achievements so far while looking toward a new stratum of success with clear-eyed gratitude.
The Fayetteville rapper’s debut album is at its best when he shines a light on his darkest moments and traces his glow-up step-by-step, imbuing each word with purpose.
Serving up his customary collage of UK garage rhythms, forlorn vocals, sugary trance synths, and copious vinyl hiss, Burial is at his most emo on a new split EP.
The Japanese jazz saxophonist’s debut arrived at the intersection between traditional and unfamiliar, mannerly and chaotic. A new reissue restores it to its rightful place.
Somewhere between a demo collection, a live album with no audience, and a lo-fi left turn, the ad-hoc country trio’s desert recording session focuses on the simple joys of songwriting.
Veering from bubblegum house to shoegaze, the producer and singer captures the intimacy of the dancefloor.
Countering the isolation of the past year, the UK house producer draws upon classic club sounds in an EP guided by the life-giving virtues of community.
The English band’s nervy debut blazes through scraps of jazz, funk, krautrock, dub, and punk. More than a canonized style, it’s their level of control that sets them apart.
Sam Beam’s earliest recordings reveal a songwriter and singer already secure in his eccentricities. Far from sounding tentative, these songs are more like a lost Iron & Wine album.
Massachusetts songwriter Cooper Handy’s naive, bizarro-world pop is a portal to a dimension weirder and more vivid than this one.

album: Fiver With the Atlantic School of Spontaneous Composition
description: Simone Schmidt and company navigate interior and exterior life with country-inflected improvisations that stretch out like a long summer afternoon.
In composing radiant new-age music inspired by plants, the Los Angeles-based musician encourages a sense of empathy with nonhuman life.
Straying from the niche where he made his name, the fingerstyle guitarist layers his playing with field recordings and electroacoustic techniques, to cryptic but compelling ends.
Reworking improv sessions featuring frequent collaborators like Sam Gendel, Jamael Dean, and Laraaji, the L.A. bandleader and percussionist shows his contemplative side.
A posthumous album captures the legendary drummer and Afrobeat icon at his most copacetic and polished, meeting collaborators at their level even as he urges them to his.

Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today we revisit the cosmic country rockers’ 1969 debut, a strange, short-lived truce in the long battle between hippies and squares.
In his score to LeSean Thomas’ anime series about a Black samurai in medieval Japan, the Los Angeles musician aligns his visual obsessions with his wide-ranging musical instincts.

Although Dodie Clark came to fame for her chatty and intimate viral videos, she proves the exception to the rule about internet stars making terrible music. Her debut studio album spotlights the sparse and self-conscious folk-pop she’s been making for nearly a decade.
Ambitious, self-referential, and packed with their signature bad puns, the D.C. emo-punk duo’s double album hones in on the nostalgia and sincerity that lies beneath all adolescent woe.
Dylan Brady’s experimental pop troupe finds idiosyncratic takes on late-aughts pop, but gets bogged down by great gecspectations and its leader’s own overwhelming influence.
On this mini-album, the K-pop girl group struggle to maintain the audacious energy that first put them in the spotlight.
With sharp DIY production and earnestly self-aware lyrics, Eric Reyes’ debut radiates familiar, understated emo-pop charm.
It’s a terrible night for a moondance: On this risible and intermittently lovely 28-song collection, Van indulges in some of his most cherished paranoid theories and deepest-held grudges.

album: Boogie Shoes: Live on Beale Street
description: This live set captures the former Big Star frontman for a 1999 one-off in Memphis, where he serves up a feast of soul-music staples backed by the city’s legendary Hi Rhythm Section.
The Toronto singer’s latest is a time capsule of moody 2010s R&B, distinguished by its introspection and near-claustrophobic melancholy.
With production by Peter Kember and an added gospel choir, the Danish band’s fifth album completes their transformation from grim-faced nihilists to wearied soothsayers.

album: if i could make it go quiet
description: The 22-year-old pop songwriter’s debut captures the onslaught of young-adult emotion, longing for a state of being where noise and confusion are replaced by certainty and clarity.
The Virginia crooner reintroduces himself with a set of sumptuous, retro R&B that’s a soothing, dapper fit for his impressive vocal range.
16 years after their original underground classic, Matt Sweeney and Will Oldham reunite for an album that plays like the continuation of a decades-long conversation.
The Scottish band’s eleventh album feels uniquely pensive, even tentative. Nearly every song will have you humming along, though few seem designed to grab your attention.
The indefatigable punk icon reworks his anthemic 2020 album   as ska, and wouldn’t you know, it works.
The garage-rock institution rolls on with a loosely conceptual album that is equally inconsistent and ingenious, containing some of Robert Pollard’s most direct lyricism.
A new compilation recaps the career of the Belgian synth-pop trio, whose futuristic kitsch stretched from the Eurovision Song Contest to the roots of Detroit techno.
The latest album from the Toronto saxophonist, best known for his work with Destroyer, is an inventive work of auditory storytelling exploring his own fraught religious background.
Setting aside his penchant for elaborate concept records, the UK producer zeroes in on what makes his productions so singular, balancing immaculate sound design with compelling club rhythms.

album: Pink Dogs on the Green Grass
description: The cartoonist and drummer for the post-punk quintet Pottery explores gently lysergic visions on his psych-pop solo albums.
For almost two decades, Dawn Richard has been increasingly beholden to nothing but her own satisfaction as an independent artist. Her sixth album is a decadent testament to her maturation.

Each Sunday, Pitchfork takes an in-depth look at a significant album from the past, and any record not in our archives is eligible. Today we revisit the British folk-rock singer’s 1976 album, a brilliant display of musicianship from a songwriter attuned to the mysteries of desire and heartbreak.
On her least country album to date, the Nashville songwriter flattens out the twang and borrows from pop and hip-hop, to mixed results.
Refining her approach, the Japanese musician shifts from singer-songwriter confessionalism to open-ended abstraction on this textured, ambient record.
Across two long, imperceptibly evolving tracks, the veteran drone duo delivers a pair of luxuriant tonal sound baths.
The Montclair, NJ-based rapper follows his breakout debut with an expansive, funk-embroidered recollection of his childhood, complete with an accompanying 35-minute film.

Coming seven years after his debut, the North Carolina EDM producer’s second album alternates between euphoric pop and muted ambient work, exploring the difficulty of finding fulfillment and lasting peace.
Faithfull pairs her forever-soothing voice with the words of the Romantic poets who inspired her, over tasteful accompaniments from Bad Seeds sonic architect Warren Ellis.
More intimate and less reverential than a traditional remix album, collaborator Richard Barratt’s full-length rework casts   in deeper shades of modern house and techno.
Snoop’s new album, the latest in a quietly prolific period as he closes in on 50, reminds of the simple pleasures of his still-virtuosic voice when set against booming, funk-inflected production.
On a set of ominous club tracks billed as a dystopian concept record, the Bristol native brings an industrial edge to that city’s deeply ingrained soundsystem sensibilities.
Lil Yachty consummates his unlikely relationship with Michigan rap on a mixtape pairing him with mainstays like Sada Baby and Rio da Yung OG.
The DFA stalwart delivers a set of psychedelic, late-night club cuts that invoke the dancefloor at its most immersive.
In Hayden Anhedönia’s moody, gothic soundscapes, the ageless persona of Ethel Cain confronts the religion, sex, and violence lurking within the confines of small-town America.
The Pakistan-born, Brooklyn-based composer draws from jazz, Hindustani classical, and folk to create a heartbreaking, exquisite document of the journey from grief to acceptance.
For the final installment in his years-long genre study of house music, the L.A. funk prophet takes a different structural approach while maintaining a minimalist spirit.
At his best, the stalwart Memphis rapper excels at heart-on-sleeve, bluesy songwriting, and his new album shows him deepening and opening up.
